G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, G.L. c. 186, § 14 guarantees a tenant the right to quiet enjoyment of their rental property, free from serious interference by the landlord or their failure to make necessary repairs.

Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).proposition: (landlords’ failure to address significant habitability issues constitutes breach of quiet enjoyment).
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).support_reasoning: The case involves serious and persistent habitability defects (no heat, structural disrepair, infestation, code violations) that the landlord failed to remedy despite complaints and court orders. Although the court ultimately bases the tenant’s substantial recovery on breach of the implied warranty of habitability and on emotional distress and c. 93A, the opinion accepts the Housing Court’s determination that the tenant prevailed on a counterclaim for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and treats the landlord’s failure to correct the grave conditions as actionable. Thus, it supports the general proposition that a landlord’s failure to address significant habitability problems can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment, even though the quiet enjoyment analysis is not elaborated in detail.
Haddad v. Gonzalez, 410 Mass. 855 (1991).relevant_excerpt: After a trial, a judge of the Housing Court found in favor of Gonzalez on all of her counterclaims and awarded her damages under c. 186, treble damages under c. 93A (for the intentional infliction of emotional distress and violation of the warranty of habitability), and attorneys' fees and costs. … After his view, the judge made express findings. Among other defects, the judge found that: (1) there was no functioning heating system; … (8) the apartment was infested with cockroaches and rodents. … The judge ordered Haddad to repair most of the defects… [but] the inspector found that virtually all of the defects… remained unrepaired.

Lashley v. Siedzak, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 53.raw_text: Lashley v. Siedzak, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 538 (1997)
Lashley v. Siedzak, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 53.proposition: (landlord liable for failure to address water intrusion and resulting mold).
Lashley v. Siedzak, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 53.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns automobile and umbrella insurance coverage and whether an umbrella policy had lapsed before an accident. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, water intrusion, habitability, or mold, nor does it discuss landlord liability for failing to address such conditions. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for landlord liability for water intrusion and mold.
Lashley v. Siedzak, 42 Mass. App. Ct. 53.relevant_excerpt:
“The judge was correct in concluding that the CU umbrella policy expired on November 30, 1989, and was not in effect at the time of the accident the next day.

Judgment affirmed.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: (mold and water damage can support claims for breach of habitability and quiet enjoyment).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case squarely involves recurrent flooding (water and sewage) that caused unsanitary, uninhabitable conditions in the tenant’s apartment. The court affirms a jury verdict for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and holds that repeated flooding interfering with sanitary conditions supports both habitability and statutory quiet enjoyment claims (though the quiet enjoyment damages award was vacated as duplicative, not for lack of liability). While mold is not mentioned, water damage and unsanitary flooding are recognized as sufficient bases for these claims.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “We have held that every landlord that rents residential property warrants to its tenants that the premises will be delivered and maintained in a habitable condition… At a minimum, this warranty imposes on the landlord a duty to keep the dwelling in conformity with the State Sanitary Code… There was evidence at trial that the wall between Solomon’s apartment and the adjoining basement area was extremely porous… a section of the State Sanitary Code… provides that apartments must be watertight… Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”}

Dolores v. Gustafson, 12 Mass. L. Rptr..raw_text: Dolores v. Gustafson, 12 Mass. L. Rptr. 157 (2000)
Dolores v. Gustafson, 12 Mass. L. Rptr..proposition: (failure to repair pervasive water leaks supports breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14).
Dolores v. Gustafson, 12 Mass. L. Rptr..support_reasoning: The provided opinion in Dolores v. Gustafson deals entirely with discovery disputes, attorney‑client privilege, and the Open Meeting Law in the context of town officials and building permits. It does not concern landlord‑tenant law, conditions of residential premises, water leaks, or any claim under G.L. c. 186, § 14. Therefore, it cannot be authority for the proposition that failure to repair pervasive water leaks supports a breach of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Dolores v. Gustafson, 12 Mass. L. Rptr..relevant_excerpt: The plaintiffs in this action challenge actions taken by the defendant Town of Hopkinton (the town) and certain of its officials which the plaintiffs claim purposefully deprived them of their civil rights in relation to the development of building lots they own in the town. The principal focus of the plaintiffs’ complaint is the persistent refusal of the defendants to permit the issuance of building permits for the lots, which has allegedly prevented their development or sale.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: (landlords must maintain habitable conditions in rental units).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion (even though it is a concurrence/dissent) expressly advocates abandoning the old caveat emptor rule and recognizing that landlords of dwelling units have an obligation, for the benefit of tenants, to meet minimum habitability standards set by statute and the State Sanitary Code. It states that by renting a dwelling, the landlord impliedly agrees that it complies with those standards and will be maintained accordingly, and that this obligation is interdependent with the tenant’s duty to pay rent. That directly supports the proposition that landlords must maintain habitable conditions in rental units.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: (persistent failure to address hazards breaches covenant of quiet enjoyment).
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses sanitary code violations and awards damages for breach of the warranty of habitability and related statutory violations, but it does not analyze or even mention a covenant of quiet enjoyment claim. The court characterizes most conditions as having a ‘minimal impact’ and focuses only on rent abatement and statutory remedies, not on whether persistent failure to address hazards constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
“Several violations of the State Sanitary Code…have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs…

Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability… The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.”

Lin v. Summer St. Corp., 2006 WL 554744,.raw_text: Lin v. Summer St. Corp., 2006 WL 554744, No. 03-04551 (Mass. Super. Ct. 2006)

Molehaus Trust v. Goldstein, 333 Mass. 1.proposition: (landlord knowledge and inaction is key to establishing breach).
Molehaus Trust v. Goldstein, 333 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a zoning variance for use of land as an off‑street parking lot and turns entirely on the statutory requirement of ‘hardship’ related to the particular parcel. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, landlord knowledge, inaction, or breach of any landlord duty. Therefore it does not support the proposition that landlord knowledge and inaction is key to establishing breach.
Molehaus Trust v. Goldstein, 333 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Under § 30 the board of appeals was empowered to grant a variance ‘where, owing to conditions especially affecting such parcel but not affecting generally the zoning district in which it is located, a literal enforcement of [the zoning ordinance] would involve substantial hardship to the appellant, and where desirable relief may be granted without substantial detriment to the public good and without substantially derogating from the intent or purpose of [the ordinance], but not otherwise.’”

Spack v. Barnett, 269 Mass. 494 (1929).proposition: (law imposes significant duties on landlord to ensure tenant enjoyment).
